text: In death phase, the number of cells that die in a given time period is proportional to the number that existed at the beginning of the time period.
The death rate can be expressed as a half-life, the time over which a population declines by half.
Note that the nice, smooth exponential growth microbes growing in natural environments or in complex laboratory media containing multiple carbon and energy sources.
Although death curves are basically logarithmic, exact death rates are difficult to define because mutations arise that promote survival, and some cells grow by cannibalizing others.
Determining microbial death rates is critical to the study of food preservation and to the development of antibiotics (further discussed in Chapters 5, 16, and 27).

Some bacterial species produce odd-looking growth curves in complex media as the population depletes one carbon source and must switch physiology to instead, it smoothly transitions through a series of metabolic states.
In fact, a portion of the cells will often survive for months, years, or even decades.
Consequently, the death phase is extremely prolonged.
Thus, the death rate is a negative exponential function.
Like the growth rate, the death rate—the rate at which cells die— is logarithmic.
Cells begin to die, and the culture enters the death phase.
toxic chemicals present in the environment.
